Efficient and bifunctional catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is crucial for achieving of easily-operable water electrolysis. Herein, Ni,Fe sulfides embedded N,S co-doped carbon hybrids (NiFeS@NSCs) with tunable Ni:Fe ratios were devised through pyrolysis of methionine chelated Ni, Fe precursors. In this type of heterojunction hybrids, the spontaneous diffusion of electrons from embedded sulfides to NSC shell increases the reducibility of NSC and the oxidizability of sulfides, which are therefore capable of catalyzing OER and HER simultaneously. The typical Ni2FeS@NSC hybrid with Ni:Fe molar ratio of 2:1 offered high electrocatalytic ability for alkali OER (overpotential of 247 mV at 10 mA cm−2), which is significantly superior to that of individual sulfide. In addition, good HER efficiency was concurrently ensured by Ni2FeS@NSC. The symmetric water electrolyzer based on Ni2FeS@NSC required an input voltage of 1.77 V to arouse an electrolysis current density of 10 mA cm−2. This work offers a feasible approach to enhance the OER, HER bifunctional catalytic performances via interfacial electrons diffusion within heterojunction hybrid. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Bimetallic sulfide Heterostructure Charge redistribution Oxygen evolution reaction Hydrogen evolution reaction 1 Introduction Hydrogen is a clean and high calorific value (142 MJ kg−1) energy carrier that can relieve the over-reliance on fossil fuel, which conforms to the future peak carbon dioxide emission, carbon neutrality aims and therefore attracts extensive attention. Water electrolysis is a promising approach to produce pure hydrogen using clean electric energy, but the unfavorable kinetics for anodic OER and cathodic HER cause high overvoltage. As a result, high energy consumption is needed to expedite the hydrogen generation rate, which inevitably increases the cost for hydrogen production [1,2]. Hence, it is imperative to develop appropriate electrocatalysts to accelerate the reaction kinetics during water electrolysis. Despite the noble metals based catalysts, e.g. IrO2, RuO2 and Pt/C can significantly expedite OER and HER, individually, their exorbitant costs and monofunctional catalytic behaviors restrict the industrial-scale water electrolysis. In this context, the OER, HER bifunctional catalysts based on non-precious elements are highly pursued to accomplish practical water electrolysis for hydrogen fuel production. In general, due to the catalytic selectivity, a monocomponent catalyst commonly owns specific catalytic behavior (exclusive for oxidation or reduction reaction). The binary hybrid composing of an oxidative and a reductive catalyst combines the characteristics of both components and creates bifunctionality, thus enables easily-operable water electrolysis [3–5]. More importantly, the spontaneous diffusion of electrons across the contact interface driven by Fermi levels gap causes the energy band bending at heterointerface and alteration in electronic structures, therefore significantly reinforce the oxidizability/reducibility of individual components, which are crucial for water electrolysis. Hence, a series of heterostructured hybrids, including p-n junction hybrids [6], Mott-Schottky junctions [7,8] and carbon based heterojunction hybrids [9–13] were constructed to enhance the OER, HER bifunctional catalytic properties via interfacial electronic interactions. Taking p-n junction nanohybrid as a sample, driven by the gap in Fermi levels, the electrons at n-type semiconductor component diffuse spontaneously across heterointerface to p-type side until the balanced state with equal Fermi levels, the down-shifted valence band (VB) energy level of n-type component enhances its oxidizability and therefore the OER catalytic ability. Simultaneously, the up-shifted conduction band (CB) energy level reinforces the reducibility of p-type component [6]. In a word, the charge redistribution across the heterointerface activates the dissociation of water molecule and intermediates, therefore concurrently enhances the OER and HER abilities. Likewise, the spontaneous interfacial charge redistribution between metal and semiconductor across the Mott-Schottky junction, as well as the electronic interaction within carbon based heterojunction hybrid are responsible for the enhanced bifunctional catalytic performances in water electrolysis. In this sense, the construction of nanointerface between OER and HER components is a feasible pathway to achieve bifunctional water oxidation/reduction, and further enables the assembly of water electrolyzer in easily-operable and magnifiable manner. In term of non-precious components for heterojunction catalysts, due to the similar valence shell electrons configurations to noble meals, Fe, Co, Ni based compounds, including oxides, chalcogenides, phosphides and alloys were documented as OER or HER catalysts, comparable and even superior water electrolysis catalytic efficiencies to noble metal based counterparts were harvested via compositional tuning and microstructural design [14–16]. Thereinto, sulfides are especially intriguing for the higher conductivities over the corresponding oxides for the narrower band gaps, therefore can reduce the overpotential for OER. The further formation of bimetal sulfide, such as Ni,Fe sulfide can modulate the local electronic structures of Ni, Fe sites via the electrons migration across the bridged S within octahedral lattice, thus optimize the adsorption energies for water molecule, intermediates and interface charge transfer, which are responsible for maximized OER, just resemble to that in Fe doped Ni hydroxides (oxide) [17,18]. Moreover, sulfides are common n-type semiconductor with high Fermi levels (slightly beneath the CB), upon hybriding with carbon, the electrons at sulfide can flow spontaneously to carbon across heterointerface driven by the Fermi levels gap, therefore enhances the oxidizability of sulfide component whereas the reducibility of carbon component. Given the fact that heteroelements doped carbons are common catalysts for water electrolysis and oxygen reduction due to the modified electrophilicity/nucleophilicity and altered Fermi levels [19,20], the hybrids composing of doped carbons and transition metal sulfides are envisioned to be feasible candidates as highly active and low cost bifunctional catalysts for water electrolysis via interfacial electronic interactions. Based on these considerations, herein, a Ni2FeS@NSC hybrid was prepared and attempted as bifunctional catalyst for water electrolysis. The interface electrons diffusion from embedded sulfide to NSC enhanced the oxidizability and therefore the OER catalytic activity of sulfide component, and the hybrid also demonstrated enhanced HER catalytic feature, therefore contribute to the bifunctional features for water electrolysis. The current work highlights the significance of charge redistribution within hybrid to OER, HER catalytic efficiencies and provides a universal pathway to enhance the bifunctional catalytic features in more widespread application fields. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Ni2FeS@NSC The sources of reagents were shown in Supporting information. To prepare NiFeS@NSCs, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O with total dosage of 2 mmol whereas different molar ratios (1:0, 1:1, 2:1, 3:1 and 0:1), were codissolved in 10 mL deionized water, 2 mmol of methionine was then added under vigorous stirring for 30 min to form a dark green chelate solutions, which were then dried at 80 °C to afford the precursors. The collected precursors were placed individually in porcelain boats and pyrolyzed in a N2 filled tube furnace. The temperature of furnace was initially raised to 400 °C and maintained for 2 h, then elevated to 800 °C and maintained for another 2 h at ramping rate of 5 °C min−1 to form NiFeS@NSCs. The yielded products were concretely denoted as NiS@NSC, NiFeS@NSC, Ni2FeS@NSC, Ni3Fe@NSC and FeS@NSC, respectively according to Ni:Fe ratios, all of them were collectively called as NiFeS@NSCs. In controlled experimental, NSC was prepared by direct pyrolysis of methionine via the same method. Mere Ni2FeS was hydrothermally prepared using thiourea as S source, in brief, 1.33 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.66 mmol Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 5 mmol thiourea were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water for hydrothermal reaction at 180 °C for 5 h. 2.2 Characterizations and electrode fabrication The structural and surface characterizations of the catalysts were demonstrated in Supporting information. The energy levels of NSC and Ni2FeS@NSC were measured via ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS, VG Scienta R4000 analyzer irradiated by He I monnnochromatic light source (21.22 eV)) combined with ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV–vis, DRS 7-SCSpec DRA-2500 spectrometer). The Tauc plot was converted from UV–vis follows: (αhν)2 = K(hν-Eg), α, hν, K represent the absorption coefficient, photoenergy and material associated constant). The catalytic electrode for electrochemical tests was fabricated as follows: 5.0 mg of catalyst, 1.0 mg Ketjen black and 20 μL 5.0 wt% Nafion solution were ultrasonically dispersed in 1 mL isopropanol to form a homogeneous ink, which was coated onto a piece of precleaned Ni foam substrate (1 ×1 × 0.1 cm3) at a net loading amount of 0.5 mg for application as working electrode. The RuO2 and Pt/C (20 wt%) electrodes were also fabricated likewise for comparison. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The alkali OER, HER properties of the catalytic electrodes were assessed in 30 mL of 1 M KOH aqueous electrolyte bubbled respectively with high purity O2 and N2 beforehand. All of the electrochemical data were recorded by a Chenhua CHI 760E electrochemical workstation, and the three-electrode test system encompasses an above fabricated working electrode, a carbon rod counter electrode and a AgCl/Ag (in 3.0 M KCl inner electrolyte) reference electrode. To intuitively reflect the electrochemical process, the recorded potential (E) was calibrated against reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to: E(vs RHE)=E(vs AgCl/Ag)+ 0.197 + 0.059 pH [21]. The polarization curve of catalytic electrode was depicted through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) at potential scan rate of 5 mV s−1 free of inner resistance (IR) compensation, and the catalytic kinetics was demonstrated by Tafel curve via the overpotential (η) versus logarithmic current density (logJ) correlation (η = blog|J|+a) in LSV, herein the η was calculated by: η = E(vs RHE)− 1.23 V for OER or η = E(vs RHE) V for HER. Prior to OER test, cyclic voltammetry (CV) within 1.0–1.6 V (vs RHE) at 10 mV s−1 was performed for 100 cycles to achieve stable J. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) for OER was performed at 1.53 V (vs RHE) within 0.01–100 kHz with an ac perturbation of 5 mV. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of catalytic electrode for OER was evaluated by electric double-layer capacitance (C dl), which was determined via potential scan rates dependent CVs within non-faradic potential range, C dl equaled the slope of half cathodic-to-anodic current density difference (ΔJ/2 = (J anodic-J cathodic)/2) vs scan rate plots [22]. Moreover, the OER, HER stabilities were evaluated via chronopotentiometry (v-t curves) at 10 and − 10 mA cm−2, respectively, as well as the variations in LSVs after 3000 consecutive CVs at 10 mV s−1. To inspect the actual performance of bifunctional catalyst in water electrolysis, a symmetric water electrolyzer was assembled by parallel arrangement of two identical Ni2FeS@NSC electrodes with a distance of 3 cm, which was labeled as Ni2FeS@NSC//Ni2FeS@NSC device, LSV (at 5 mV s−1) and v-t curve (at 10 mA cm−2) of the device were measured in two-electrode system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fundamental design idea and characterizations Ni2FeS@NSC was devised via chelation of Ni, Fe ions by a sulfur containing amino acid (methionine) and the subsequent pyrolytic sulfuration of meal ions and carbonization of amino acid ligand ( Scheme 1). The amino and carboxyl groups in methionine serve as ligands chelating Ni, Fe ions to form uniform complexes with isolated central metals, thus alleviates the over agglomeration of the resultant sulfide nanoparticles in the formed hybrid, and further benefits the sufficient contact of two components and exposure of interface to electrolyte. Moreover, the methionine ligand in the precursor serves as S, N and C sources for the formation of sulfide and NSC framework. The S sites onto NSC shell tightly immobilize the formed sulfide nanoparticles, therefore guarantee efficient electrons diffusion across the heterointerface driven by the Fermi levels gap, the sufficient charge separation in the formed heterojunction therefore furnishes different electrophilic/nucleophilic microregions and polar surface enabling the chemisorption and oxidation/reduction of reactants [23–25], which are essential for OER, HER bifunctional catalysis. In this sense, the Ni2FeS@NSC is envisioned to be a feasible bifunctional catalyst in water electrolysis. Fig. 1a presents the powdery X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of NiFeS@NSC, Ni2FeS@NSC and Ni3FeS@NSC, all of them exhibit similar diffraction peaks, which can be largely indexed to orthorhombic Fe4Ni5S8 phase. Concretely, the peaks at 15.3, 29.5, 31.0, 35.7, 47 and 51.4 ° correspond to the (111), (311), (222), (400), (511), and (440) planes (red labels, JCPDS: 86–2470) [26,27], indicative of the formation of bimetal sulfides by pyrolytic sulfuration (Fig. S1). In addition, the minor peaks at 21.7, 31.0, 37.7, 44.1, 49.7 and 55.3 ° are indexable respectively to the (101), (110), (003), (202), (113) and (122) planes of Ni2S3 (blue labels, JCPDS: 85–1802) [28], suggesting the coexistence of other impurity phase. In contrast, the XRD patterns of NiS@NSC and FeS@NSC are assigned respectively to Ni2S3 (JCPDS: 85–1802) [28] and Fe0.96S phases (JCPDS: 50–1788) [29] (Fig. S2a,b), showing the different phases of sulfide components. Noted that the bulk Ni2FeS hydrothermally sulfurated by thiourea includes both NiS and FeS phases (Fig. S2c), suggesting the respective sulfuration of Fe, Ni ions. From these results, the pyrolytic sulfuration at high temperature is responsible for the bimetallic sulfide phase within NiFeS@NSCs. The morphologies of the samples are characterized by scanning electrons microscopy (SEM), NSC mainly demonstrates irregular blocks with rough surface (Fig. 1b), which, together with the amorphous phase, suggest the formation of random carbonaceous blocks by direct pyrolysis of methionine. The Ni2FeS@NSC demonstrates island like agglomerates composing of well-defined primary nanoparticles (Fig. 1c), showing the loading of sulfide particles onto/within the carbonaceous framework. No apparently peeled particles are observable, implying the tight connection between sulfide particles and NSC framework, which is beneficial for durability in rigorous electrochemical process. The observable inter-particle voids signify the highly porous texture, and N2 sorption isotherm also verifies the mesoporous texture with Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area (SBET) of 75 m2 g−1 (Fig. S3). Such a porous texture allows the filling of reactants and the sufficient access to inner surface, therefore maximizes the catalytic performance. NiFeS@NSC, Ni3FeS@NSC, NiS@NSC and FeS@NSC also demonstrate the similar porous textures to Ni2FeS@NSC (Fig. S4 and S5). The interior texture of Ni2FeS@NSC was observed by transmittance electrons microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 1d, the low magnification image displays irregular agglomerates with translucent appearance throughout the structure, showing the porous texture. In addition, the alternative scattering of dark particles throughout the sample is mainly originated from the homogeneous embedding of sulfide nanoparticles within NSC network. High resolution TEM (HRTEM) further evidences the porous texture with enriched interparticle voids (Fig. 1e). The dark particles are indexable to sulfide, for the heavy metal atoms are hard to be penetrated by electrons beam and therefore display dim region with sharp contrast against the background. Lattice fringes with spacing of 0.304 nm are observable throughout the particles, which correspond well to the (311) planes of Ni2FeS, more unequivocally verify the thermal sulfuration of Ni, Fe ions. Moreover, the incontinuous curve fringes seamlessly circled around the sulfide particles are mainly attributable to the turbostatic carbon shells with low graphitization degree as a result of the enriched structural defects and heteroelements. Partial regions of the shells exhibit interplanar spacing of 0.34 nm, which implies that partial NSC exists in form of graphene layers, also suggest the embedding of sulfide within NSC matrix. In this core-shell structure with tight encapsulation of tiny bimetal sulfide nanoparticles (around 15 nm) into NSC network, the intimate contact between the two components constructs well-defined interface and ensures efficient charge redistribution, and the porous texture allows the sufficient exposure of space charge region (nanointerface) to electrolyte, therefore enable effective charge transfer with reactants and further contribute to high catalytic properties [30]. As for bulk Ni2FeS (Fig. S6), the morphology features fused particles with nonporous texture, showing the fusion and growth of the nucleus toward dense blocks by hydrothermal sulfuration. Raman spectra of the samples are also compared, from Fig. 1f and Fig. S7, the hybrids demonstrate two major peaks at 1350 and 1580 cm−1, which are ascribable respectively to the defects and disorders at the edges of graphitic network (D band), as well as the graphitic skeleton with ideal aromatic lattice (G band) of carbonaceous material [31,32]. The almost identical intensities of D and G bands suggest the containing of abundant defects and heteroatom doping sites within the graphitic framework, these peaks prove the inclusion of NSC in the hybrids. In addition, the weak vibrations at 500 and 700 cm−1 (inset) are assignable to the F 2 g and A 1 g vibrations of Ni(Fe)-S bonds, which suggest the formation of sulfides by pyrolytic sulfuration. EDS mappings of Ni2FeS@NSC display the homogeneous distributions of Fe, Ni, S, N and C elements throughout the bulk structure (Fig. S8), showing the homogeneous embedding of sulfide within the NSC framework. The existence of O element is mainly originated from the survived O from methionine and the inevitable surface oxygen replacement of sulfide component. The elemental composition and interface charge redistribution within the typical Ni2FeS@NSC were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). From Fig. 2a, the survey spectrum shows the coexistence of C, N, S, O, Ni, Fe elements with atomic ratio of 75.2:3:1.5:17.8:1.7:0.8, preliminary suggesting the inclusion of sulfide and NSC components in the hybrid. Of note the O element is mainly derived from the residual O in NSC and the eremacausis of sulfide component. As a comparison, the NSC prepared by calcination of methionine also contains N, S, O and C elements, evidencing the decoration of N, S and O functionalities within/onto the carbonaceous framework. These heteroelements increase the surface polarity and wettability to water molecule and hydroxyl ions, which are essential for surface catalysis. Moreover, the S sites tightly immobilize the sulfide via covalent bonds, the interface charge redistributions therefore reinforce the electrophilicity/nucleophilicity at different microregions, which are pivotal for catalytic activity and bifunctionality of Ni2FeS@NSC. Fig. 2b compares the C1s XPS of Ni2FeS@NSC and NSC, both spectra comprise a series of sub-peaks at 284.6, 285.5, 286.3 and 288.9 eV, which are assignable in turn to the CC/C-C skeleton and C-S/C-N, C-O, CO functionalities [33,34], verifying the doping of S, N, O into the carbonaceous motif. Relative to NSC, the binding energy (BE) of C1s down shifts by 0.2 eV in Ni2FeS@NSC, showing the electrons transfer from embedded sulfide to NSC shell. S2p XPS of the two samples are also compared (Fig. 2c), both spectra share three sub-peaks at 162.6, 163.7 and 167.9 eV, which are assignable respectively to C-S (S2p3/2 and S2p1/2) and sulfuryl S (SOx 2-) groups [33,35], showing the decoration of S functionalities onto carbon motif. Moreover, the additional sub-peak assignable to the S2p3/2 orbit of Ni,Fe-S bonds (161.5 eV) in Ni2FeS@NSC suggests the inclusion of embedded sulfide [36]. More detailed observation reveals that the BE of C-S bonds down shifts by 0.4 eV relative to NSC, the more conspicuous decrement over that of C1s XPS offers the clue of electrons diffusion from embedded sulfide to NSC shell through the S sites within Ni2FeS@NSC. N1s XPS of Ni2FeS@NSC (Fig. 2d) includes four sub-peaks assignable to pyridinic-, pyrrolic-, graphitic- and oxidized-N (398.2, 399.3, 400.7 and 402.4 eV, respectively) [37,38], verifying the doping of N onto different positions of graphitic network. Thereinto, the pyridinic-N containing a localized electron can serve as Lewis base site for chemisorption of water molecule and donate electron for the cleavage of H-O bond toward adsorbed H atom [39], which is beneficial for HER. The Ni2p XPS of Ni2FeS@NSC can be fitted into two peaks at 853.3 and 870.6 eV ascribable to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 spin orbits of Ni(II) [40,41], as well as other two peaks ascribable to Ni(III) (856.0 eV for 2p3/2 and 873.0 eV for 2p1/2 orbits) [40,41]. These results verify the coexistence of both Ni(II) and Ni(III) species. To monitor the interface charge transfer within Ni2FeS@NSC, Ni2p XPS of bulk Ni2FeS is compared. Relative to bulk Ni2FeS, the Ni(III) sub-peaks enhance obviously in Ni2FeS@NSC, which tentatively imply the deviation of electrons from embedded sulfide to NSC shell. Fe2p XPS of Ni2FeS@NSC and bulk Ni2FeS are also compared (Fig. 2f), both spectra include sub-peaks assignable to Fe(II) (710.6 and 724 eV for Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 orbits) and Fe(III) (712.6 and 725.8 eV for Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 orbits) [42], as well as two satellite peaks assignable to the spin coupling of unpaired electrons within Fe(II). The additional peak at 707 eV in bulk Ni2FeS is ascribable to Fe(0) hydrothermally reduced by thiourea, which resembles to that in other case [43]. Despite the variations in Fe(II) and Fe(III) species are not obvious in XPS, the substantial decrement in satellite peaks associated with Fe(II) suggest the increased nominal oxidation value in Ni2FeS@NSC. Based on these results, the increased nominal oxidation values of Ni, Fe and the reduced BEs of C1s and S2p orbits evidence the efficient electrons diffusion from embedded sulfide to NSC shell, thus reinforces the nucleophilic trend of NSC shell and electrophilicity of sulfide component, which are beneficial for bifunctional catalytic properties of Ni2FeS@NSC. Moreover, the doped N, S, O functionalities enhance the polarity and hydrophilicity of the carbonaceous framework, thus reduce the adsorption energies for water molecule and associated intermediates. Hence, the OER and HER catalytic properties can be enhanced concurrently by the intercomponent charge transfer. The intercomponent electronic interaction and electronic structure variation within the Ni2FeS@NSC were further investigated by UPS and UV–vis. Due to the individual Ni2FeS component can not be directly synthesized, the UPS of NSC and Ni2FeS@NSC are compared. From the linearly extrapolated secondary cutoff edges of UPS to baseline ( Fig. 3a), the cutoff BEs are 17.22 and 17.34 eV for NSC and Ni2FeS@NSC. According to E Φ =hv-(E cutoff-E F) (E Φ: work function, hv: photon energy, 21.22 eV, E F: Fermi energy level) [44], and the assumption that the energy level of free electron is 0 eV (E Φ = E 0), the E Fs are estimated to − 4.00 and − 3.88 eV, respectively for NSC and Ni2FeS@NSC. Moreover, the linearly extrapolated intercept at baseline in the near Fermi edge of UPS equals the gap between VB and E F (E F-VB) [44]. As shown in Fig. 3b,c, E F-VB values are 1.63 and 1.94 eV, respectively for NSC and Ni2FeS@NSC, accordingly, the VBs are − 5.63 and − 5.82 eV, respectively relative to vacuum level. Moreover, based on the Tauc curve derived from UV–vis (inset in Fig. 3b), the optical band gap of NSC is 1.86 eV. From these data, the energy band structure of NSC can be drawn, as depicted by the left diagram in Fig. 3d, the VB of NSC (−5.63 eV) lies slightly over the maximum water oxidation potential (−5.73 eV), whereas the CB lies within the potential range for water reduction (over −4.5 eV), so it can be inferred that NSC is inert for OER while active for HER [6]. Upon formation of Ni2FeS@NSC, the E F elevates from − 4.00 to − 3.88 eV (right diagram in Fig. 3d), which signifies the spontaneous electrons diffusion from sulfide to NSC across the heterointerface, hence the reducibility and further the HER activity of NSC component are reinforced, this assumption coincides with the trends in XPS (Fig. 2). On the contrary, the VB of Ni2FeS@NSC declines to − 5.82 eV, which lies beneath the maximum water oxidation potential, so the OER activity of sulfide component is also enhanced. From the perspective of energy level structure, Ni2FeS@NSC is capable of catalyzing both OER and HER. 3.2 OER properties OER properties of the catalytic electrodes were measured in O2 saturated 1 M KOH solution. Prior to OER test, the catalyst was activated by100 CVs till the achieving of a stable response current (Fig. S9). During this process, the J at 1.6 V increases gradually and the anodic peak shifts slightly from 1.4 to 1.45 V, while an additional cathodic peak appears at 1.3 V (vs RHE). These differences are probably due to the surface layer of sulfide is gradually evolved into fresh (oxy)hydroxide upon electrooxidation, which can serve as additional active sites for OER and finally contribute to OER efficiency [45,46]. Fig. 4a presents the LSVs of NiS@NSC, FeS@NSC, Ni2FeS@NSC, NSC, bulk Ni2FeS, RuO2 and bare Ni foam electrodes at 5 mV s−1 without IR compensation, which feature a weak anodic peak and a sharp rise in J due to OER at higher potential. Specifically, the much lower J s and larger ηs for Ni foam substrate and NSC electrode suggest the inertness of Ni foam and NSC for OER. The bulk Ni2FeS electrode displays an onset potential of 1.49 V and η of 300 mV to arouse J = 10 mA cm−2 (η 10), suggesting the mediocre OER catalytic efficiency. In contrast, the J of OER increases saliently at Ni2FeS@NSC electrode, which needs a η 10 of 247 mV, and the η 10 value can reduce to 235 mV by 85% IR compensation (Fig. S10). In addition, the J of Ni2FeS@NSC is even higher over the sum by Ni2FeS+NSC (inset in Fig. 4a), showing the significant role of intercomponent synergy to OER efficiency. The η 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC is also obviously lower than RuO2 (η 10 =347 mV), manifesting the competitiveness of the hybrid in OER catalysis. Moreover, the J of Ni2FeS@NSC is also higher over that of NiS@NSC and FeS@NSC electrodes (Fig. S11), which bring out the critical role of embedded bimetal sulfide to OER, this trend is reminiscence to the synergy in NiFe layered double hydroxides or oxides [17,18]. The Js and η 10s of NiFeS@NSC and Ni3FeS@NSC are also inferior to Ni2FeS@NSC, hence, the Ni2FeS@NSC herein is the optimal OER catalyst. Fig. 4b compares the η 10s and Js at 1.7 V (J 1.7s) of different electrodes, the smaller η 10 (247 mV) of Ni2FeS@NSC over bulk Ni2FeS and NSC manifests the enhanced OER catalytic efficiency by the core-shell hybrid, in which the charge redistribution across the heterointerface reduces the energy barriers of O containing species in the multi-step process, therefore expedites the reaction kinetics and reduces the η. In addition, the η 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC is also lower than its cousins at other Ni:Fe ratios, showing the optimal composition of the former hybrid. Moreover, the Ni2FeS@NSC electrode arouses J 1.7 value of 169 mA cm−2, which is substantially higher over the rest electrodes (101, 54, 96, 104, 41, 64 and 66 mA cm−2, respectively for RuO2, NiS@NSC, FeS@NSC, Ni2FeS, NSC, NiFeS@NSC and Ni3FeS@NSC electrodes), further manifesting the much pronounced OER at the former electrode. In this Ni2FeS@NSC hybrid, the spontaneous electrons transfer from embedded bimetallic sulfide to NSC shell leads to the positive charge and descends the VB of sulfide component, which reinforce the chemisorption of O-containing intermediates and increases the oxidizability, therefore expedite the OER process. In addition, the partial surface evolution from sulfide into (oxy)hydroxide during electrochemical process also contributes to the OER efficiency. The η10 of Ni2FeS@NSC is lower than the documented sulfides or carbonaceous composites catalysts, including Co9S8@NSC (304 mV, IR compensated) [47], CoSx@Cu2MoS4-MoS2/NSG (351 mV, IR compensated) [48], ZnCoS-NSCNT/NP (270 mV, IR compensated) [35], NiCo4S@NSC (270 mV in 0.1 M KOH, IR compensated) [49], comparable to NiFeS/NF (231 mV, IR compensated) [50], c-Fe-CoxSy/C (247 mV) [51] and FexNi1−xS2/C (248 mV) [52], whereas higher over NiFeS/CoS (170 mV at 50 mA cm−2) [53] and Cu-Ni3S2/Co3S4 (160 mV at 50 mA cm−2) [54]. From these comparisons, the Ni2FeS@NSC herein is competitive in OER catalysis. The OER kinetics of the electrodes were revealed by Tafel curves and EISs. From Fig. 4c, the Tafel slope of Ni2FeS@NSC is 79 mV dec−1, which is lower than that of NiS@NSC (120 mV dec−1), FeS@NSC (100 mV dec−1), NiFeS@NSC (150 mV dec−1), Ni3FeS@NSC (215 mV dec−1), bulk Ni2FeS (116 mV dec−1), NSC (105 mV dec−1) and RuO2 (85 mV dec−1), implying the faster OER kinetics at Ni2FeS@NSC. EISs of all electrodes show negligible disparities in real intercepts (Fig. S12), which suggest the similar total series resistances (R s s) due to the similar compositions of catalysts and the same test condition. The arc at high-frequency zone represents the charge-transfer resistance (R ct), the smaller R ct value corresponds to a faster electron transfer rate, namely the higher OER catalytic efficiency [55,56]. From the diameters of the arcs, the R ct s are 0.35, 0.29, 0.56, 0.26, 0.44, 0.53, 0.46 and 0.64 ohm, respectively for NiS@NSC, FeS@NSC, NiFeS@NSC, Ni2FeS@NSC, Ni3FeS@NSC, bulk Ni2FeS, NSC and RuO2 electrodes. The smallest R ct of Ni2FeS@NSC electrode implies the most rapid charge transfer kinetics, viz. the highest catalytic efficiency for OER. To identify the contribution of accessible surface area to OER efficiency, C dl s of the electrodes were estimated through the scan rates dependent CVs within non-faradic potential range (Fig. S13), which are proportional to the ECSAs. Fig. 4e shows the ΔJ/2 vs scan rate plots of the electrodes, the slopes of the plots correspond to C dl s [57,58]. As summarized in Table S1, the C dl is 19.7 mF cm−2 for Ni2FeS@NSC electrode, which is almost 2 times higher than that of Ni2FeS, NSC and 3 times higher than that of RuO2, showing the exposure of more catalytically active sites for chemisorption of OH- and O-containing intermediates, which contribute partially to the OER efficiency. To further identify the intrinsic OER catalytic activity irrespective of the surface contribution, C dl s normalized Js (J/C dl s) in LSVs are re-plotted in Fig. 4f, the J/C dl value of Ni2FeS@NSC is lower than bulk Ni2FeS, showing the lower intrinsic catalytic activity, so the higher OER efficiency is contributed more by the increased ECSA. The more accessible heterointerface to electrolyte and the increased oxidizability are co-operative in enhancing the OER efficiency. The J/C dl of Ni2FeS@NSC is also slightly lower than its cousins with other Ni:Fe ratios, showing the higher catalytic efficiency is overwhelmingly contributed by the more abundant surface sites. Given the slightly lower intrinsic activity whereas substantially higher C dl , the optimal OER catalytic efficiency is therefore achieved by Ni2FeS@NSC. The OER stabilities of different electrodes were assessed and compared by v-t curves (Fig. 4f). The η 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC electrode gradually attenuates with fluctuation from 252 to 247 mV, which accounts for 5 mV decrement after 24 h, showing the excellent OER stability. The durability of bulk Ni2FeS is also rather stable (η 10 increases from 292 to 300 mV under the same condition). In contrast, the η 10 increases from 312 to 347 mV for RuO2 electrode, implying the severe decay in catalytic activity. Moreover, the LSVs of Ni2FeS@NSC electrode before and after 3000 CVs at 10 mV s−1 are also compared (inset), an obvious oxidation peak turns up at about 1.45 V (vs RHE) after CV cycles, which is attributed the formation of superfacial (oxy)hydroxide due to surface replacement and oxidation in alkali electrolyte at high potential, and the overpotential also increases slightly, showing the surface evolution of sulfide and slight decay in OER during electrochemical cycles. The morphology, phase and surface elemental composition of Ni2FeS@NSC electrode after v-t-test were further monitored. SEM indicates that the Ni2FeS@NSC is still composed of well-defined nanoparticles (Fig. 14a), no observable changes occurs relative to its initial morphology. XRD pattern also demonstrates its initial phases free of additional diffractions (Fig. 14b). So it can be inferred that the shallow layer surface evolution during cycling test does not cause discernable morphological or phase alternation. XPS of Ni2FeS@NSC (Fig. S15) reveals the remaining of Ni(III) and Fe(III) species, suggesting the electrooxidation of sulfide component to afford Ni(III)oxyhydroxide and Fe(III)oxyhydroxide, which are common active sites for OER, therefore contribute to the OER stability to some extent. Based on these results, the Ni2FeS@NSC is also a rather durable OER catalyst. 3.3 HER properties To accomplish easily-operable water electrolysis, efficient HER catalytic feature is also essential, so the HER properties of the aforementioned electrodes were also evaluated, and the Pt/C electrode was also measured for comparison. From the LSVs in Fig. 5a, the onset potential and J of Ni2FeS@NSC are superior to the bulk Ni2FeS and NSC, showing the feasibility of the former hybrid in HER catalysis, although the J is still not comparable to Pt/C. It is assumed that the charge redistribution elevates the CB of NSC (Fig. 3d), which enhances the reducibility for HER. The ηs at − 10 mA cm−2 (η 10s) are 271, 301, 334 and 122 mV for Ni2FeS@NSC, bulk Ni2FeS, NSC and Pt/C electrodes. Obviously, the η 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC is lower than the bulk Ni2FeS and NSC, which roughly highlights the promoting effect by charge redistribution between sulfide and NSC. To be mentioned, with further decrement in operation potential, J of Ni2FeS@NSC elevates more prominently than Pt/C, and the J value outperforms the Pt/C below − 0.42 V, showing the higher hydrogen production rate at higher η, hence, the Ni2FeS@NSC herein is more suitable for hydrogen production at higher η or operation voltage. With 85% IR compensation, η 10 reduces to 215 mV (inset), also evidencing the good HER catalytic property. The core-shell hybrids at different Ni:Fe atomic ratios are also compared (Fig. S16), the onset potential and J of Ni2FeS@NSC electrode are obviously superior to the others, showing that the Ni2FeS@NSC herein is the optimal HER catalyst. Fig. 5b summarizes the J 0.5s (Js at −0.5 V) and η 10s of these electrodes. The J 0.5 of Ni2FeS@NSC is the highest in all electrodes, showing the more sufficient HER at low operation potential. In addition, the η 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC is also lower than other non-Pt electrodes. Comprehensively considering these major indicators, Ni2FeS@NSC herein is the most efficient non-precious HER catalyst. The Tafel plots of all electrodes are shown in Fig. 5c, as observed, the Tafel slopes are 103, 115, 114, 108, 148, 112, 102 and 48 mV dec−1 respectively for NiS@NSC, NiFeS@NSC, Ni2FeS@NSC, Ni3FeS@NSC, FeS@NSC, bulk Ni2FeS, NSC and Pt/C electrodes. The higher slopes of all non-precious electrodes relative to Pt/C counterpart suggest the slower HER kinetics at the former catalysts. Moreover, the approximately 120 mV dec−1 Tafel slopes for all hybrids mean that the reductive dissociation of water molecule at catalysts surface is the kinetically limiting step during HER process. Concretely, the adsorptive dissociation of H-OH bond and reduction by an electron to form adsorbed H atom at catalyst surface (catalyst+H2O+e=catalyst-H+OH-, Volmer step) is the rate limiting step for HER [59,60]. Herein, the partially filled 3d orbits of Ni, Fe cations within sulfide component allow the chemisorption of water molecule and weaken the O-H bond, and the nucleophilic feature of NSC benefitted by interface charge redistribution (electrons transfer from sulfide to NSC) promotes the formation of adsorbed H atom, which guarantee the subsequently rapid formation and quick desorption of afforded H2 molecule [61]. To further identify the concrete catalytic component for HER, KSCN, as a poison reagent for metallic sites [62], was incorporated into the alkali electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 5d, the LSV almost completely overlaps with the initial one, which exclude the HER catalytic effect of Ni2FeS component. Given the low HER catalytic efficiency of mere NSC, the interface charge redistribution substantially enhances the reducibility of NSC and further the HER efficiency. The HER stabilities of Ni2FeS@NSC and Pt/C electrodes are compared by v-t curves (Fig. 5e), η 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC electrode increases from 273 to 310 mV after 24 h, the decay in HER efficiency is less severe than that of Pt/C electrode (η 10 increases from 122 to 200 mV), showing the better HER durability of the former electrode. Besides, the LSVs of Ni2FeS@NSC electrode before and after 3000 CVs within 0～− 0.5 V at 10 mV s−1 are also compared, the J decays at low potential, showing the attenuated catalytic activity undergoes rigorous electrochemical cycles. Based on all of these comparisons, the Ni2FeS@NSC herein is also an active and durable HER catalyst. 3.4 Full water electrolysis performances Motivated by the superior OER property and the additional HER catalytic behavior of Ni2FeS@NSC, the overall water electrolysis performances of the symmetric water electrolyzers (denoted as catalyst//catalyst), as well as the asymmetric RuO2//Pt/C system using RuO2 as OER anode and Pt/C as HER cathode are compared. From the LSVs in Fig. 6a, an input voltage (V 10) of 1.77 V is needed to deliver a water electrolysis current density of 10 mA cm−2 for the Ni2FeS@NSC//Ni2FeS@NSC electrolyzer, which is higher over that for RuO2//Pt/C electrolyzer (V 10 =1.68 V) for the inferior HER property of Ni2FeS@NSC. In another comparison, the V 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC//Ni2FeS@NSC device is lower than the bulk Ni2FeS//Ni2FeS device (V 10 =1.84 V), showing the vital role of heterostructured Ni2FeS@NSC hybrid catalyst in water electrolysis. Moreover, the V 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC//Ni2FeS@NSC electrolyzer is also lower than NiS@NSC//NiS@NSC (V 10 =1.81 V), NiFeS@NSC//NiFeS@NSC (V 10 =1.79 V), Ni3FeS@NSC//Ni3FeS@NSC (V 10 =1.80 V), FeS@NSC//FeS@NSC (V 10 =1.83 V) and NSC//NSC device (V 10 =1.83 V) (Fig. 6b). Considering the acceptable input voltage while the facile preparation of non-precious Ni2FeS@NSC catalyst, the Ni2FeS@NSC//Ni2FeS@NSC electrolyzer owns the potential for bulk production of hydrogen fuel. The V 10 of Ni2FeS@NSC//Ni2FeS@NSC electrolyzer is largely in accordance with the potential difference between OER anode and HER cathode, showing the avoidance of unnecessary voltage loss in this symmetric water electrolyzer. In addition, the water electrolysis stability of Ni2FeS@NSC//Ni2FeS@NSC electrolyzer is assessed by v-t plots at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6c), the V 10 increases slightly from 1.77 to 1.80 V after 24 h, the 30 mV increment implies the good durability upon continued operation. By a traditional drainage gas collection method, the H2 and O2 producing rates at both electrodes are measured at 2 V (inset), the as-collected H2:O2 volume ratio is 2:1, which suggests the identical Faradic efficiencies of Ni2FeS@NSC at anode and cathode. This result visually evidences the good OER, HER bifunctional catalysis behaviors in actual water electrolysis. 4 Conclusions To summarize, a Ni2FeS@NSC heterojunction hybrid was prepared via pyrolysis of methionine chelated Ni, Fe salts precursor. The charge redistribution within Ni2FeS@NSC enhances the oxidizability of Ni2FeS core and reducibility of NSC shell, and the porous texture increases the exposure of heterointerface to electrolyte, therefore high catalytic efficiencies for OER and HER can be ensured, the OER catalytic efficiency is comparable to the mainstream level of currently documented sulfides based catalysts. The symmetric water electrolyzer based on the Ni2FeS@NSC catalyst displays acceptable water electrolysis voltage and good stability in alkali medium. This work provides a general and effective way to accomplish efficient bifunctional catalysis through interface charge redistribution in heterostructured hybrid. coredata.dc:description: Efficient and bifunctional catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is crucial for achieving of easily-operable water electrolysis. Herein, Ni,Fe sulfides embedded N,S co-doped carbon hybrids (NiFeS@NSCs) with tunable Ni:Fe ratios were devised through pyrolysis of methionine chelated Ni, Fe precursors. In this type of heterojunction hybrids, the spontaneous diffusion of electrons from embedded sulfides to NSC shell increases the reducibility of NSC and the oxidizability of sulfides, which are therefore capable of catalyzing OER and HER simultaneously. The typical Ni2FeS@NSC hybrid with Ni:Fe molar ratio of 2:1 offered high electrocatalytic ability for alkali OER (overpotential of 247 mV at 10 mA cm−2), which is significantly superior to that of individual sulfide. In addition, good HER efficiency was concurrently ensured by Ni2FeS@NSC. The symmetric water electrolyzer based on Ni2FeS@NSC required an input voltage of 1.77 V to arouse an electrolysis current density of 10 mA cm−2. This work offers a feasible approach to enhance the OER, HER bifunctional catalytic performances via interfacial electrons diffusion within heterojunction hybrid.
coredata.dc:title: Heterostructured nickel, iron sulfide@nitrogen, sulfur co-doped carbon hybrid with efficient interfacial charge redistribution as bifunctional catalyst for water electrolysis
